ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot of new grammar, Kanji, and developed my speaking and reading skills.
basic Japanese reading, writing, grammar, and vocabulary and a basic understanding of Japanese culture and traditions
I learned more Japanese and understood more about Japanese culture.

By taking this course I enhanced my knowledge of the basics of the Japanese language. I learned how to read, write, and understand over 100 kanji, lots of basic Japanese vocabulary (mostly for everyday life), how to use a wide variety of grammar, and how to better my Japanese pronunciation.
I learned much more vocabulary and grammar, to the point where fluent conversation is possible.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is extremely well organized to facilitate learning. Homework and clinics also make learning topics easier.

strengths: Yamaguchi sensei is an amazing teacher who is very responsible and caring for her students; the course textbook Tobira is great and has interesting material; the curriculum is well designed and extremely organized; very high level of engagement in class you feel like you get to know the teacher and your classmates well; there is a good amount of homework every day but they are easy and once you get used to it the workload is quite manageable and predictable
weaknesses: Japanese clinic (a weekly meeting of two students and one teaching fellow to practice speaking) can be a hit or miss depending on your TF; my TF in JAPN 110 was great but my TF in this class was always ten minutes late to our clinic and they always explained things in an unnecessarily detailed way that I almost felt like they just wanted to pass time
The strength was Mika Yamaguchi. She's a wonderful teacher and she's very engaging. The homework was not that difficult, but it furthered my understanding. I don't recall there being any weaknesses.
I really like that the course is very organized. Everything was very easy to follow and it was helping for my learning. We also had a lot of opportunity to practice the grammars and vocabularies.

This course is well organized and structured in a way that was very conducive to learning the Japanese language in a way that naturally build upon itself. You really do learn an amazing amount of Japanese. However, this class does require quite a bit of work. There's a good amount of homework every night and the learning pace of the class is pretty fast.
Very persistent, however, there were so many assignments and tools to use as homework that it could become overwhelming.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The clinics and breakout rooms helped us meet new people and therefore become much more engaged in the class.
Yamaguchi sensei was very familiar with all the Zoom and Canvas features so that helped make our class as productive and efficient as possible!
The group projects could be improved. With the different time zones and all the Zoom events happening, it is slightly difficult to do them.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! But only if you're passionate about learning a new language. The workload is very high and you will spend much time outside of class dedicated to Japanese. You'll learn a ton in a short amount of time.
YES! Amazing, caring and responsible professor, fun textbook and material, well-designed and well-organized curriculum

I would recommend this class, especially with Yamaguchi Sensei. She's a wonderful teacher. The workload is never overwhelming, she's engaging, and she is willing to make conversation in Japanese and help you in whatever you need.

I would definitely recommend this class for anyone really interested in learning Japanese. The class is a commitment, there's a good amount of homework every night and the learning pace of the class is pretty fast. But, if you're dedicated, you really do learn an amazing amount of Japanese. Further, Yamaguchi-sensei is an amazing teacher! The course is well organized and structured in a way that was very conducive to learning the Japanese language in a way that naturally build upon itself.
If you are interested in learning more and connecting with Japanese culture and language, then yes.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: weekly Japanese clinics
4 days a week live seminar + 1 day a week asynchronous work
N/A
This class was a live virtual lecture held over Zoom with lots of discussion components and breakout rooms to practice skills with other classmates.
Asynchronous day each week for tests and projects.
